module.p:
Name-descriptions are names which are not (single) nouns. They consist of a specified common noun phrase which identifies and refers to a particular entity – a specific person, place, group . Examples of name-descriptions are –
Bean Alasdair Alexander’s Wife
Am Ploc Plockton
Gàidhlig na h-Èireann Irish Gaelic

Name-descriptions contrast with proper nouns (names which are also nouns) –
Mairead
Margaret
Glaschu
Glasgow
Gairm [literary periodical]
In addition, most specified common noun phrases (‘definite descriptions’) are not names, e.g. am balach beag the little boy, cù a’ mhinisteir the minister’s dog.

section.p:
Name-descriptions can be classified into two grammatical types, based on the position of the specifier –
pre-specified name-descriptions – the common noun element is specified by a determiner –
Am Moireach The Duke of Atholl; lit. The Murray
dative – leis a’ Mhoireach
genitive – taigh a’ Mhoirich
An Gearasdan Fort William; lit. The Garrison
dative – anns a’ Ghearasdan
genitive – meadhan a’ Ghearasdain
An Seann Tiomnadh The Old Testament
dative – anns an t-Seann Tiomnadh
genitive – leabhraichean an t-Seann Tiomnaidh
post-specified name-descriptions – the common noun element is specified by a following genitive word or phrase –
Fear Chìosmuil MacNeil of Barra; lit. The Man of Kisimul
dative – le Fear Chìosmuil
genitive – taigh Fear Chìosmuil [alt. taigh Fhir Chìosmuil]
Baile Ùr an t-Slèibhe Newtonmore; lit. The New Town of the Hillside
dative – ann am Baile Ùr an t-Slèibhe
genitive – meadhan Baile Ùr an t-Slèibhe
Òran na Cloiche The Song of the Stone
dative – ann an Òran na Cloiche
genitive – fonn Òran na Cloiche

Unlike proper nouns, name-descriptions can be grammatically plural –
Na Crìochan The Borders
dative – anns na Crìochan
genitive – comhairle nan Crìochan
Crìochan na h-Alba The Scottish Borders
dative – ann an Crìochan na h-Alba
genitive – comhairle Crìochan na h-Alba

Note that, in pre-specified name-descriptions, the definite article is capitalised in some contexts but not in others, depending on the grammatical/communicative context and the semantic class of the name.

Like all names, name-descriptions can also be classified into a number of semantic types, depending on the kind of entity named –
Anthroponymic name-descriptions name individual persons (including personified entities) – An Còirneal The Colonel, Fear Chanaigh The Man of Canna [John Lorne Campbell].
Toponymic name-descriptions name places (geographical and cosmological entities) – Am Ploc Plockton, Baile Ùr an t-Slèibhe Newtonmore, A’ Mhaidneag The Morning Star [Venus].
Ergonymic name-descriptions name groups, teams, organisations, companies – An Comunn Gàidhealach The Highland Association, Comhairle nan Leabhraichean The Gaelic Books Council.
Chrematonymic name-descriptions name songs, poems, stories and other creative works – Am Bìoball The Bible, Òran a’ Phrionnsa The Song of the Prince, Faclair na Gàidhlig The [Historical] Dictionary of Scottish Gaelic.
Glottonymic name-descriptions name languages and dialects – A’ Ghreugais Greek, Gàidhlig na h-Èireann Irish Gaelic.
Chrononymic name-descriptions name events and historical eras – An Cogadh Mòr The Great War, Linn an Umha The Bronze Age.

Note that a few pre-specified name-descriptions are notable in that the nouns involved appear to be more proper than common, in particular names of countries (e.g. A’ Ghreug Greece) and languages (e.g. A’ Ghreugais Greek). For convenience, we can call these ‘uncommon’ nouns – syntactically common but semantically proper.

The head (ie. initial) noun in a post-specified name-description which is itself the genitive (post-)specifier of another noun is generally not lenited in Scottish Gaelic –
anthroponymic – taigh Fear Chìosmuil MacNeil of Barra’s house
toponymic – mullach Beinn Nibheis the summit of Ben Nevis
ergonymic – ceannard Bòrd na Gàidhlig the chairman of Bòrd na Gàidhlig
chrematonymic – Ionad Faclair na Gàidhlig The Centre for Faclair na Gàidhlig
glottonymic – faclair Gàidhlig na h-Alba dictionary of Scottish Gaelic
chrononymic – deireadh Cogadh a’ Chamais the end of the Gulf War

However, when a toponymic name-description denotes a town or city, it is often lenited –
muinntir Dhùn Èideann the people of Edinburgh
